<!--https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/be#be__3-->
<h1><i class="i">Be</i></h1>            <div class="fcdo-s20">from <a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/english-grammar-today/" class="a--rev">English Grammar Today</a></div>
</div><div class="content"><div class="section_anchor" id="be-forms"> </div><div class="section"><div class="header"><h2 class="title"><i class="i">Be</i>: forms</h2></div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">Be</i> is an irregular verb with several forms:<span class="target"/></p><p class="p"><b class="b">Present</b>: (I) <i class="i">am</i>, (he, she, it) <i class="i">is</i> (you, we, they) <i class="i">are</i> + <i class="i">-</i><b class="b"><i class="i">ing</i></b> <b class="b">form</b>: <i class="i">being</i></p><p class="p"><b class="b">Past</b>: (I, he, she, it,) <i class="i">was</i>, (you, we, they) <i class="i">were</i> + -<b class="b"><i class="i">ed</i></b> <b class="b">form</b>: <i class="i">been</i></p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">I<b class="b">’m</b> in college at the moment.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">Where <b class="b">is</b> she?</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">He <b class="b">was</b> her first husband.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">Were</b> you at the U2 concert?</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">The weather <b class="b">has been</b> really nice since June.</i></p></blockquote></div></div><div class="section_anchor" id="be-uses"> </div><div class="section"><div class="header"><h2 class="title"><i class="i">Be</i>: uses</h2></div><div class="content"><p class="p">We use <i class="i">be</i> as a main verb and an auxiliary verb.</p><div class="nav"><p class="p">See also: </p><ul class="ul"><li class="li"><p class="p"> <a class="Ref" href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/be#be__3"><i class="i">Be</i> as a main verb </a> </p></li><li class="li"><p class="p"> <a class="Ref" href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/be#be__5"><i class="i">Be</i> as an auxiliary verb </a> </p></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="section_anchor" id="be-as-a-main-verb"> </div><div class="section"><div class="header"><h2 class="title"><i class="i">Be</i> as a main verb</h2></div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">Be</i> as a main verb has a number of meanings.<span class="target"/></p><div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title">Qualities</h3></div><div class="content"><p class="p"><span class="target"/>We use <i class="i">be</i> to talk about permanent or temporary qualities or states:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">He<b class="b">’s</b> very rich.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">My father <b class="b">is</b> old now.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">The weather <b class="b">was</b> terrible.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">The food <b class="b">is</b> so good in Italy.</i></p></blockquote><div class="panel pad-indent"><div class="panel-head"><span class="panel-title">Warning: </span></div><div class="panel-body pad-indent"><p class="p">When we use <i class="i">there</i> as a subject with <i class="i">be</i>, we use <i class="i">there is</i> + singular noun and <i class="i">there are</i> + plural noun:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">There <b class="b">are</b> lots of wonderful places to see on the south coast.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p">Not: <s class="s">There is lots of wonderful places</s> …</p></blockquote></div></div><div class="nav"><p class="p">See also: </p><ul class="ul"><li class="li"><p class="p"> <a class="Ref" href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/there-is-there-s-and-there-are"><i class="i">There is</i>, <i class="i">there’s</i> and <i class="i">there are</i> </a> </p></li></ul></div></div></div>      <div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title">Nationality and group identity</h3></div><div class="content"><p class="p">We use <i class="i">be</i> to talk about our nationality and our identity within groups or clubs:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">Is</b> she Irish or English?</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">I <b class="b">am</b> an Arsenal fan.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">He<b class="b">’s</b> <b class="b">been</b> a member of the rowing club for twenty years.</i></p></blockquote></div></div><div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title">Jobs and professions</h3></div><div class="content"><p class="p">We can use <i class="i">be</i> to talk about a person’s job or profession. Note the use of <i class="i">a</i> with singular names of jobs and professions:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">He’<b class="b">s</b> a firefighter.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p">Not: <s class="s">He’s firefighter</s>.</p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">Both of my brothers <b class="b">are</b> policemen.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">My grandmother <b class="b">was</b> a nurse.</i></p></blockquote></div></div>
<div id='ad_contentslot_1' class='am-default contentslot'>
</div>
<div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title">Age</h3></div><div class="content"><p class="p">We use <i class="i">be</i> to talk about age:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">I <b class="b">was</b> seventeen when I met Bob.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">Because I <b class="b">wasn’t</b> eighteen, I couldn’t vote in the last election.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">How old <b class="b">is</b> she?</i></p></blockquote></div></div><div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title">Relationships</h3></div><div class="content"><p class="p">We use <i class="i">be</i> to talk how people are related:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">He <b class="b">is</b> my first cousin.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">They <b class="b">are</b> my best friends.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">Are</b> you her sister?</i></p></blockquote></div></div>      <div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title">Place</h3></div><div class="content"><p class="p">We can use <i class="i">be</i> to refer to where places and things are situated:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">Her house <b class="b">is</b> on the edge of the lake.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">The shops <b class="b">are</b> at the end of the street.</i></p></blockquote></div></div>
<div id='ad_contentslot_2' class='am-default contentslot'>
</div>
<div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title">Time</h3></div><div class="content"><p class="p">We use <i class="i">be</i> to talk about time and dates:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">What time <b class="b">is</b> it?</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">The match <b class="b">was</b> at seven o’clock.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">We <b class="b">are</b> always late!</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">The meeting <b class="b">is</b> on the fifth of October.</i></p></blockquote></div></div>      <div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title">Behaviour and personality</h3></div><div class="content"><p class="p">We can use <i class="i">be</i> to talk about behaviour and personality:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">He <b class="b">was</b> always gentle.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">Is</b> she nice?</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">The children <b class="b">can be</b> rough with the new puppy.</i></p></blockquote><p class="p">When we talk about a way of behaving at the moment of speaking, we use the continuous form of <i class="i">be</i>:<span class="target"/></p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">You<b class="b">’re being</b> too generous.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">Ignore him. He<b class="b">’s</b> just <b class="b">being</b> silly. <b class="b"><span class="target"/></b></i></p></blockquote><p class="p">We use <i class="i">be</i> to describe feelings and situations:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">I <b class="b">was</b> very happy.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">Are</b> you hungry?</i></p></blockquote></div></div></div></div><div class="section_anchor" id="modal-expressions-with-be"> </div><div class="section"><div class="header"><h2 class="title">Modal expressions with <i class="i">be</i></h2></div><div class="content"><p class="p"><b class="b"><span class="target"/></b>There are a number of expressions with <i class="i">be</i> which have modal meanings, for example, <i class="i">be to, be able to, be allowed to, be supposed to</i>:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">Will</b> Martin <b class="b">be able to</b> get everyone in his car?</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">We <b class="b">were supposed to</b> get there an hour ago.</i></p></blockquote><div class="nav"><p class="p">See also: </p><ul class="ul"><li class="li"><p class="p"> <a class="Ref" href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/be-expressions-be-able-to-be-due-to"><i class="i">Be</i> expressions (<i class="i">be able to</i>, <i class="i">be due to</i>) </a> </p></li><li class="li"><p class="p"> <a class="Ref" href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modality-other-modal-words-and-expressions#modality-other-modal-words-and-expressions__3">Modality: expressions with <i class="i">be</i> </a> </p></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="section_anchor" id="be-as-an-auxiliary-verb"> </div><div class="section"><div class="header"><h2 class="title"><i class="i">Be</i> as an auxiliary verb</h2></div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">Be</i> is one of three <span class="target"/>auxiliary verbs in English: <i class="i">be</i>, <i class="i">do</i> and <i class="i">have</i>. We use <i class="i">be</i> to make the continuous form and the passive voice<span class="target"/>: <b class="b"><span class="target"/></b></p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">I<b class="b">’m reading</b> a book about the Titanic at the moment.</i> (continuous)</p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">What <b class="b">was</b> she <b class="b">doing</b> in France?</i> (continuous)</p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">The job <b class="b">was advertised</b> last week.</i> (passive)</p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">The house <b class="b">was being painted</b>.</i> (continuous and passive)</p></blockquote><div class="panel pad-indent"><div class="panel-head"><span class="panel-title">Warning: </span></div><div class="panel-body pad-indent"><p class="p">We don’t use auxiliary <i class="i">be</i> to make questions with main verbs in the present simple. We use auxiliary <i class="i">do</i>:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">Do</b> you <b class="b">live</b> near here?</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p">Not: <s class="s">Are you live near here?</s></p></blockquote></div></div><div class="nav"><p class="p">See also: </p><ul class="ul"><li class="li"><p class="p"> <a class="Ref" href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/present-continuous-i-am-working">Present continuous (<i class="i">I am working</i>) </a> </p></li><li class="li"><p class="p"> <a class="Ref" href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/past-continuous-i-was-working">Past continuous (<i class="i">I was working</i>) </a> </p></li><li class="li"><p class="p"> <a class="Ref" href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/passive">Passive </a> </p></li><li class="li"><p class="p"> <a class="Ref" href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/do#do__4"><i class="i">Do</i> as an auxiliary verb </a> </p></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="section_anchor" id="be-typical-errors"> </div><div class="section"><div class="header"><h2 class="title"><i class="i">Be</i>: typical errors</h2></div><div class="content"><ul class="ul"><li class="li"><p class="p"><b class="b"><span class="target"/></b>Remember <span class="target"/>to use <i class="i">are</i> for the third person plural form of <i class="i">be</i>:</p></li></ul><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">The company’s profits <b class="b">are</b> lower this year.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p">Not: <s class="s">The company’s profits is lower this year</s>.</p></blockquote><ul class="ul"><li class="li"><p class="p">We use <i class="i">there is</i> + singular noun and <i class="i">there are</i> + plural noun:</p></li></ul><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">There are</b> so many great <b class="b">restaurants</b> here.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p">Not: <s class="s">There is so many great restaurants here</s>.</p></blockquote><ul class="ul"><li class="li"><p class="p">We use auxiliary <i class="i">do</i>, not auxiliary <i class="i">be</i>, for questions with main verbs in the present simple:</p></li></ul><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">Do</b> you <b class="b">accept</b> credit cards?</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p">Not: <s class="s">Are you accept</s> …</p></blockquote></div></div></div></div></article>
</div>
</div>
<div class="clrd">
<div class="mod float-xl">
<div id='ad_btmslot_a' class='am-default '>
</div>
<div id='ad_houseslot_b' class='am-default '>
</div>

</li>

</li>
<li class="section">
<a>Easily confused words</a>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/above-or-over"><i>Above</i> or <i>over?</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/across-over-or-through"><i>Across</i>, <i>over</i> or <i>through</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/advice-or-advise"><i>Advice</i> or <i>advise</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/affect-or-effect"><i>Affect</i> or <i>effect</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/all-or-every"><i>All</i> or <i>every</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/all-or-whole"><i>All</i> or <i>whole</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/allow-permit-or-let"><i>Allow</i>, <i>permit</i> or <i>let</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/almost-or-nearly"><i>Almost</i> or <i>nearly</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/alone-lonely-or-lonesome"><i>Alone</i>, <i>lonely</i>, or <i>lonesome</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/along-or-alongside"><i>Along</i> or <i>alongside</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/already-still-or-yet"><i>Already</i>, <i>still</i> or <i>yet</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/also-as-well-or-too"><i>Also</i>, <i>as well</i> or <i>too</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/alternate-ly-alternative-ly"><i>Alternate(ly)</i>, <i>alternative(ly)</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/although-or-though"><i>Although</i> or <i>though</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/altogether-or-all-together"><i>Altogether</i> or <i>all together</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/amount-of-number-of-or-quantity-of"><i>Amount of</i>, <i>number of</i> or <i>quantity of</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/any-more-or-anymore"><i>Any more</i> or <i>anymore</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/anyone-anybody-or-anything"><i>Anyone</i>, <i>anybody</i> or <i>anything</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/apart-from-or-except-for"><i>Apart from</i> or <i>except for</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/arise-or-rise"><i>Arise</i> or <i>rise</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/around-or-round"><i>Around</i> or <i>round</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/arouse-or-rouse"><i>Arouse</i> or <i>rouse</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/as-or-like"><i>As</i> or <i>like</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/as-because-or-since"><i>As</i>, <i>because</i> or <i>since</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/as-when-or-while"><i>As</i>, <i>when</i> or <i>while</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/been-or-gone"><i>Been</i> or <i>gone</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/begin-or-start"><i>Begin</i> or <i>start</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/beside-or-besides"><i>Beside</i> or <i>besides</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/between-or-among"><i>Between</i> or <i>among</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/born-or-borne"><i>Born</i> or <i>borne</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/bring-take-and-fetch"><i>Bring</i>, <i>take</i> and <i>fetch</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/can-could-or-may"><i>Can</i>, <i>could</i> or <i>may</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/classic-or-classical"><i>Classic</i> or <i>classical?</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/come-or-go"><i>Come</i> or <i>go?</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/consider-or-regard"><i>Consider</i> or <i>regard</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/consist-comprise-or-compose"><i>Consist</i>, <i>comprise</i> or <i>compose</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/content-or-contents"><i>Content</i> or <i>contents?</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/different-from-different-to-or-different-than"><i>Different from</i>, <i>different to</i> or <i>different than</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/do-or-make"><i>Do</i> or <i>make</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/down-downwards-or-downward"><i>Down, downwards or <i>downward?</i></i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/during-or-for"><i>During</i> or <i>for?</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/each-or-every"><i>Each</i> or <i>every</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/east-or-eastern-north-or-northern"><i>East</i> or <i>eastern</i>; <i>north</i> or <i>northern</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/economic-or-economical"><i>Economic</i> or <i>economical</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/efficient-or-effective"><i>Efficient</i> or <i>effective</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/elder-eldest-or-older-oldest"><i>Elder</i>, <i>eldest</i> or <i>older</i>, <i>oldest</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/end-or-finish"><i>End</i> or <i>finish</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/especially-or-specially"><i>Especially</i> or <i>specially</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/every"><i>Every one</i> or <i>everyone</i>?</a>

<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/except-or-except-for"><i>Except</i> or <i>except for</i>?</a>

<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/expect-hope-or-wait"><i>Expect</i>, <i>hope</i> or <i>wait</i>?</a>

<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/female-or-feminine-male-or-masculine"><i>Female</i> or <i>feminine</i>; <i>male</i> or <i>masculine</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/finally-at-last-lastly-or-in-the-end"><i>Finally</i>, <i>at last</i>, <i>lastly</i> or <i>in the end?</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/first-firstly-or-at-first"><i>First</i>, <i>firstly</i> or <i>at first</i>?</a>

<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/get-or-go"><i>Get</i> or <i>go?</i></a>

<li class="section">
<a>Using English</a>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/discourse-markers">discourse markers</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/emphasising-and-downtoning">emphasising and downtoning</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/functions">functions</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/numbers">numbers</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/people-and-places">people and places</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/speaking">speaking</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/types-of-english-formal-informal-etc">types of English (formal, informal, etc.)</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/useful-phrases">useful phrases</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/writing">writing</a>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="section">
<a>Verbs</a>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/about-verbs">about verbs</a>
</li>
<li class="section">
<a><i>be</i> and <i>be</i> expressions</a>
<ul>
<li class="current">
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/be-and-be-expressions/be"><i>Be</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/be-and-be-expressions/be-expressions-be-able-to-be-due-to"><i>Be</i> expressions (  <i>be able to</i>, <i>be due to</i>)</a>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/common-verbs">common verbs</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/future">future</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/infinitives-and-imperatives">infinitives and imperatives</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality">modals and modality</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/passive">passive</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/past">past</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/present">present</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/verb-patterns">verb patterns</a>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div id='ad_houseslot_a' class='am-default '>
</div>
<div class="mod mod--dark mod--style2 oflow-hide">
<div class="pad">
<p class="h2 semi-flush alt">Word of the Day</p>
<p class="h4 feature-w-big wotd-hw">taro</p><p>a tropical plant that has a root that is cooked and eaten</p>
</div>
<div class="txt-block txt-block--alt with-icons js-eqh-sticky">
<div class="with-icons__content">
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/english/taro" class="a--rev a--b">
<span>About this</span> <i class="fcdo fcdo-angle-right" aria-hidden="true"></i>
</a>
</div>
<div class="with-icons__icons">
